nirajkumar1096 wrote:
> 
> While I am not a hardcore Xp practitioner, I have used junit
> extensively. I have been attempting to find an effective framework
> that extends junit's capability to Web app testing. There are numerous
> but in my mind their effectiveness is in question.
> 
> Recently I have been trying to create a sample of automated tests for
> our enterprise web application running on Oracle 9IAS. The application
> is quite complex and uses Javascript extensively.
> My purpose is to create a test that mimics the steps in a `Change
> Request' or `Defect' . This would be created by the
> developer and
> executed before and after the bugfix/change. Therefore I needed a java
> based framework with which to create the test cases.
> 
> Since these test case need to test a web application, I researched and
> finally focused on following three options. Note that while there are
> bunch of tools/frameworks, I did not find any big winners.

I'm surprised. Here's my standard toolset:

  * XhtmlUnit to test the web UI in isolation with a sane page template 
language (not JSP).
  * HtmlUnit to test end to end through the web UI when I need it.
  * MockEJB when I need a fake JNDI context (damn Service Locator 
antipattern).
  * Cactus when I need to test CMP entity beans or JSPs.
  * ServletUnit to test the glue code between servlets and my classes.

Plain JUnit for everything else.

If you're not sure where to start, go with HtmlUnit and Cactus. When you 
get annoyed with running server-side tests, focus on refactoring to 
enable out-of-container testing, rather than searching for the next 
great test tool.

Good luck.
